user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish:
```c
void OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(OS_object_token_t *token, const osal_id_t *final_id)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;

    if (token->lock_mode == OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE)
    {
        /* nothing to do */
        return;
    }

    record = OS_ObjectIdGlobalFromToken(token);

    /* re-acquire global table lock to adjust refcount */
    if (token->lock_mode == OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE || token->lock_mode == OS_LOCK_MODE_REFCOUNT)
    {
        OS_Lock_Global(token);
    }

    if (record->refcount > 0)
    {
        --record->refcount;
    }

    /*
     * at this point the global mutex is always held, either
     * from re-acquiring it above or it is still held from
     * the original lock when using OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL.
     *
     * If an ID update was pending (i.e. for a create/delete op)
     * then do the ID update now while holding the mutex.
     */
    if (final_id != NULL)
    {
        record->active_id = *final_id;
    }
    else if (token->lock_mode == OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE)
    {
        /*
         * If the lock type was EXCLUSIVE, it means that the ID in the record
         * was reset to OS_OBJECT_ID_RESERVED.  This must restore the original
         * object ID from the token.
         */
        record->active_id = token->obj_id;
    }

    /* always unlock (this also covers OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL case) */
    OS_Unlock_Global(token);

    /*
     * Setting to "NONE" indicates that this token has been
     * released, and should not be released again.
     */
    token->lock_mode = OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish:
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_ID_RESERVED ((osal_id_t){0xFFFFFFFF})
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I did not find any uses of compiler-specific language extensions in the provided code. Specifically:

- There are no uses of recognized compiler extensions such as __attribute__, __asm__, __builtin_*, typeof (GCC extension), statement-expressions ({ ... }) as an expression, nested functions, MSVC-specific keywords, or other documented vendor extensions.
- The macro OS_OBJECT_ID_RESERVED uses a compound literal ((osal_id_t){0xFFFFFFFF}). Compound literals are a standard C99/C11 feature, not a compiler extension, so they do not trigger Rule 1.2 per the requirement to report only documented compiler extensions.
- All syntax in the function (pointer dereferences, assignments, comparisons, pre-/post-decrement, block comments, function calls) is standard C and not an extension.

Given the above, there are no code fragments that need investigation for violations of MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 (use of language extensions). If you expect a different target C standard (for example strictly C89/C90), note that compound literals are not available there; report that requirement and I can re-evaluate accordingly.
